children.name: understanding
children.definition: when you understand a situation, subject, idea etc, or sb’s ability to do this :
examples: A much greater level of understanding is required to carry out more complex experiments.
understanding of
He seems to have very little understanding of economics.
The research may lead to a better understanding of how the disease develops.
How does this add to our understanding of the problem?
If you know the neighbourhood, youhave an understanding ofwhat the children are like.
Linguists currentlyhave little understanding ofthe exact cause of language change.
have an understandingThe authorities don’t seem to have a clear understanding of the problem.
gain/get/develop an understandingScientists continued to gain a greater understanding of the effects of radiation.
deepen/broaden an understandingIt is hoped that the research will broaden our understanding of the disease.
increase/improve/enhance sb’s understandingThe classes really helped to increase our understanding of the subject.
a better/greater/deeper understandingAll of this will lead to a better understanding of the overseas market.
a clear understandingBefore you begin, it is vital that you have a clear understanding of what you want to achieve.
a complete/thorough/full understandingThe degree gives students a thorough understanding of issues relating to housing.
a proper/real understandingThey lacked any real understanding of the subject.
a good understandingThe sales force has a good understanding of the market.
a basic understandingThe aim of the examination is to test basic understanding of the written language.
a limited understandingWe have only a limited understanding of how the brain processes this information.

children.name: comprehension
children.definition: when you understand sth, especially a piece of spoken or written language, or the ability to do this : sự lĩnh hội
examples: The teacher gave us a comprehension test.
We tried to explain the causes of the war at a child’s level of comprehension.
reading comprehensionability to understand what you read
You need to practise your reading comprehension more.
beyond sb’s comprehensiontoo difficult to understand
He was caught up in frightening events far beyond his comprehension.

children.name: insight
children.definition: 1 a sudden clear understanding of something or part of something, especially a complicated situation or idea
examples: insight into
The articlegivesus a realinsightinto the causes of the present economic crisis.
The researchprovidesnewinsightsinto the way we process language.
2[U] the ability to understand and realize what people or situations are really like : sự thấu suốt
a woman of great insight
Crick soon established himself as a scientist of great insight and creativity.
insight into
We help troubled teenagers gain some insight into their own problems.

children.name: to understand sth new after studying them
digest
children.definition: to understand new information, especially when there is a large amount of it or when it is difficult to understand, by thinking about it carefully for a fairly long time: tiêu hóa, hiểu thấu
examples: ▪ The pub went silent as the villagers digested the news.
▪ By the end of the day, I had a lot of new information to digest.

children.name: take in
children.definition: to understand and remember new facts or information: lĩnh hội được
examples: I’m not going to my next class. I’m too tired to take anything in.
She listened attentively, taking in every word he said and asking questions.
take in what/why/how etc
I don’t think she really took in what I was telling her.

children.name: absorb
children.definition: to understand a large amount of new information: hấp thu
examples: ▪ Most people need to read something more than once to absorb all the ideas.
▪ He appeared to understand, but whether he absorbed every detail I cannot say.
▪ A new baby has an enormous capacity for absorbing new information.

children.name: sink in
children.definition: if a fact, information etc sinks in, you gradually understand it: ngấm dần, thấm dầm
examples: He paused to let this news sink in.
I’ve been revising all day but I don’t think much of it has sunk in.

children.name: assimilate
children.definition: to understand and use new information or ideas quickly and easily: tiêu hóa
examples: ▪ The person we are looking for must be flexible, creative, and able to assimilate new ideas.
▪ When a child is learning something new, they try to assimilate it in terms of what they already know.

children.name: to understand each part of a story, explanation etc
follow
children.definition: to understand astory,explanation, ortalkthat continues for a long time:theo kịp
examples: I had difficulty following the story - there are so many different characters.
difficult/hard/easy to follow
The lecture was very hard to follow.

children.name: be with U
children.definition: be withinformalto have understood everything so far in anexplanationthat someone is giving:theo kịp
examples: I’m sorry but I’m not with you. Could you explain that part again?
Then you press this button. Are you with me so far?

children.name: keep up
children.definition: to manage to understand each part of sth, especially a verylongorcomplicatedexplanation or story:theo kịp
examples: She covers so much in these lectures -- I don’t know how you manage to keep up.
keep up with
It’s a complicated film, and some people may find it hard to keep up with the plot.

children.name: begin to understand
children.definition: /bɪˌgɪn tʊ ʌndəʳˈstænd/  to slowly begin to understand a situation or someone’s feelings, because you get more information or because you experience something for yourself:
examples: ▪ I think it will be a long time before we even begin to understand how damaging the effect has been.
▪ Patients are given written information and videos so that they can begin to understand more about their condition.
begin to understand that
▪ I was beginning to understand that being alone could be terribly depressing.
begin to understand why/how/what etc
▪ As we walked up the narrow staircases, we began to understand why the Dutch haul their furniture up the outside of the buildings and through the windows.

children.name: catch on
children.definition: informal to begin to understand sth that is not easy to understand: hiểu được, nắm được
examples: ▪ Thomas isn’t catching on as quickly as some of the other children.
catch on to
▪ It took Jennifer a long time to catch on to the fact that Mary was taking advantage of her.
catch on fast/quickly
▪ She catches on fast and will soon be promoted.

children.name: get it
children.definition: /ˈget ɪt/  spoken to finally understand something, especially after it has been explained to you several times:
examples: ▪ Okay, I get it. You only get paid if you sell at least ten copies.
▪ ‘So the plant takes in carbon dioxide and gives out oxygen.’ ‘That’s it. You’ve got it.’

children.name: figure out
children.definition: / work outC2  to think about sth until you understand it, especially sth complicated: hiểu ra, nghĩ ra, nghiệm ra
examples: ▪ Horgan thought he had it all figured out, but he hadn’t.
figure/work something out
▪ In case you haven’t figured it out yet, we’ve been tricked.
figure/work out how/why/what etc
▪ Detectives are still trying to work out what happened.

children.name: twig
children.definition: British informal to begin to understand a situation by what you see and hear around you, and not by being told directly:
examples: ▪ Oh, I get it, I’ve twigged at last. How much do you want?
twig that
▪ At last I twigged that I was pregnanttwig
why/where/what etc
▪ It took him about two minutes to twig what I was going on about!

children.name: cotton on
children.definition: /ˌkɒtn ˈɒnǁˌkɑːtn-/  informal to begin to understand a situation by what you see and hear around you, and not by being told directly:
examples: cotton on to
▪ It took him a while to cotton on to what was happening.
▪ Large stores have at last cottoned on to the fact that mothers with pushchairs can’t cope with stairs.

children.name: click
children.definition: /klɪk/  if sth clicks, especially something you are learning, you suddenly begin to understand it:
examples: ▪ Just keep working at it, and suddenly it will all click.

children.name: fall into place
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ɪntə ˈpleɪs/  if several facts fall into place, you begin to understand how they are connected and why each one is important, so that you understand a whole situation or subject:
examples: ▪ Once the police received this new evidence, things began falling into place.
fall into place
When events or details that you did not understand before fall into place, they become easy to understand
_Once I discovered that the woman whom he had been dancing with was his daughter, everything fell into place.

children.name: to understand the meaning of sth in a particular way
make of sth U
children.partOfSpeech: [T PV not in progressive; usually in questions or negative sentences]
children.definition: make of sth to believe that sth strange, difficult, or unusual has a particular meaning: hiểu
examples: ▪ Have you read Dawson’s letter? What do you make of it?
▪ Tom could see that McCarron didn’t know what to make of the information.

children.name: read
children.definition: to think that a remark, an action, an event etc shows that sb has a particular opinion or feeling even though they do not say this directly:
examples: ▪ Good managers are usually able to read a situation quickly and take the right action.read something as something
▪ Men shouldn’t be surprised if women read this behaviour as threatening.

children.name: take sth to mean
children.definition: to choose to understand a particular meaning in sb’s words or actions without being sure that this is the correct meaning:
examples: There was a pause, which he took to mean she was angry.
Television producers should not take low ratings to mean failure.

children.name: see sth as
children.definition: to understand a remark, a piece of writing, an event etc as having a particular meaning, especially because of your own feelings, opinions, or situation:
examples: I see this poem as an attack on social injustice.
Young children often see the birth of a new brother or sister as a great threat.

children.name: interpret
children.definition: to choose to understand a piece of information or group of facts in one of several possible ways: hiểu (theo 1 cách nào đó)
examples: Fairy tales can be interpreted in several different ways.
interpret sth as sth
The statement was interpreted as a threat against the United States.
interpretation[C] C2 the way in which sb explains or understands a piece of information or group of facts : cách hiểu
One possible interpretation is that they want you to resign.
It’s difficult toputan accurateinterpretation on(= explain )the survey results.
What exactly the author meant by that statement isopen to interpretation(= able to be understood or explained in different ways ).
interpretation of
The interpretation of laboratory data is often difficult.

children.name: understand by U
children.definition: understand by to find a particular meaning in an expression or in the name of sth, even though other people may understand it differently:
examples: What do you understand by the term ‘alternative medicine’?
He spoke of profits, by which I understood profits for his company, not for us.

children.name: understand sth to mean
children.definition: understand sb/sth to mean to think that someone’s remarks, a word, a piece of writing etc means sth or has a particular message, even though this is not stated directly:
examples: ‘It’s very good. You’ll like it,’ their mother said, and gave them a look that they understood to mean they must eat it whether they liked it or not.
When he said three o'clock, I understood him to mean in the afternoon.

children.name: construe sth as
children.definition: formal to understand a remark or action in a particular way, when there are other possible ways of understanding it:
examples: Such activities by the Americans could be construed as an act of war.
Films that could be construed as offensive are shown after nine o'clock.

children.name: to understand an idea situationm or what sb is telling you
understand
children.definition: hiểu
examples: ▪ She spoke slowly and clearly so that everyone could understand.
▪ I didn’t understand the teacher’s instructions.
▪ When he’s old enough to understand, we’ll tell him he’s adopted.
understand what/why/how etc
▪ Ben asked a few questions to make sure he understood what to do.
▪ You don’t need to understand how a computer works to use it.
understand that
▪ The witness said he understood that he was swearing to give true and correct information.
easy/difficult to understand
▪ Computer manuals should be written in a way that is easy to understand.
understand perfectlyunderstand completely
▪ Don’t worry. I understand perfectly.
fully understandunderstand completely
▪ Doctors still do not fully understand the process by which the disease is transmitted.

children.name: see
children.definition: especially spoken to understand the truth about a situation, or understand the reasons for something:
examples: see what sb means
▪ Try it for yourself, and you’ll see what I mean.
see why/how/what etc
▪ I can see why people don’t like him.
I seesay this when you understand what someone has told you
▪ ‘It goes in the red box, here.’ ‘Oh, I see.’
you seesay this when you are explaining something : bạn thấy đó
▪ Well, you see, he’s not really ready to read a book this difficult.
see (that)
▪ Well, I can see that the logic is somehow wrong, but I don’t know why exactly.
see any reason : thấy lý do nào
▪ Can you see any reason why it shouldn’t work?
see the pointunderstand why something is important
▪ At fourteen, he couldn’t see the point of staying in school.
see somebody’s pointunderstand the main idea or importance of what someone is saying
▪ I didn’t like his attitude, but I could see his point.
see the jokeBritish understand why something is funny hiểu câu nói đùa
▪ He’s just one of those people who never seem to see the joke.

children.name: get your head round U
children.definition: get your head round British informal to understand something that is difficult or complicated:
examples: I just couldn’t get my head round geometry at school.

children.name: get the picture
children.definition: spoken to understand asituationorarrangement, especially one that sb is explaining to you:hiểu ( một tình huống, sự sắp xếp mà ai đang giải thích )
examples: I get the picture. You want me to say you were at my house last night.
We don’t want any trouble tonight. Do you get the picture?

children.name: get the message
children.definition: informalto understand what sb istellingyou or what theywant you to do, especially after they have told youseveraltimes:hiểu
examples: Even the Democrats got the message: voters are concerned about taxes.
get the message that
He doesn’t seem to get the message that he’s not welcome here.

children.name: make sense of
children.definition: to understand sth that isnotclearor easy to understand, especially by spending time thinking about it:hiểu
examples: Police are trying to make sense of a bizarre note left by the murderer.
There is so much information that it is difficult to make sense of it all.

children.name: grasp
children.definition: tofullyunderstand a fact or an idea, especially one that it isimportantordifficultto understand:hiếu thấu, nắm được
examples: Obviously, she had barely grasped the subject.
Science lessons should be taught in a way that makes the material easier to grasp.
At that time, we did not fully grasp the significance of what had happened.
Some people find the idea of relativity difficult to grasp.
grasp what/how etc
A short opening paragraph enables the reader to quickly grasp what the article is about.
grasp that
Nick had grasped that something was wrong.
The army had failed to grasp that their mission was to protect the navy’s ships, not vice versa.
hard to grasp
Fame has come suddenly, and Peyton is finding it hard to grasp.
grasp[U] C2
beyond sb’s grasptoo difficult to understand
Some of the historical nuances are beyond the grasp of most children.
have a grasp of sth
Cordell had an impressive grasp of military issues.

children.name: comprehend
children.definition: formalto understand sth that iscomplicatedordifficultto understand:hiểu, lĩnh hội, nhận thức thấu đáo
examples: She cannot comprehend the extent of the disaster.
comprehend what/how/why etc
It may be hard to comprehend how much this gift means for my country.
comprehend that
Finally, she comprehended that he wanted his pay.
fully comprehendunderstand something completely
The significance of the disappearance of the buffalo and the passenger pigeon was not fully comprehended until much later.
I did notfully comprehendwhat had happened.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayunderstandrather thancomprehend:
I couldunderstandmost of what she was saying.

children.name: know what sb mean
children.definition: s  to understand what someone is telling you, especially if they have not expressed it very clearly:
examples: ▪ I don’t think your audience is going to know what you mean by this.
you know what I mean?say this to check that someone understands you
▪ He seems really sad, you know what I mean?
I know what you meansay this to show that you understand
▪ ‘It’s a thing you hold pieces of wood in when you’re doing woodwork.’ ‘Oh, I know what you mean -- a vice.’

children.name: get
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: spoken informal to understand what someone says, what is happening, or why or how something happens: hiểu
examples: get it
▪ ‘Do you understand?’ ‘Yeah, we’ve got it,’ one of the drivers replied.
▪ Barbara Howell and her husband, Kenneth (Barbie and Ken, get it?) run a bed-and-breakfast inn.
I don’t get it
▪ Why did you turn down such a fantastic job? I don’t get it.
get a/the jokeunderstand why something is funny : hiểu câu nói đùa
▪ John told me one of his stupid jokes, and it took me about five minutes to get it.
get the pointunderstand the main idea or importance of something : hiểu ý chính/ việc gì quan trọng
▪ I don’t think you get the point. Legally, you must give us this information.get the idea
▪ The students should get the idea that this is a complex issue, with no easy answers.
get what/why/how etc
▪ I just couldn’t get what he meant.

children.name: understand
children.definition: verbunderstood,understoodKNOWhiểu, nhận thức được
examples: [ I or T ] to know why or how something happens or works
_[ + question word ]We still don't fully understand how the brain works.

children.name: right
children.definition: exclamationinformalAGREEMENT Hiểu rồi
examples: used to express agreement with someone or to show that you have understood whatsomeone has said
_"Johnny, you climb up first." "Right."

children.name: make sth/sb out
children.definition: makesth/sboutphrasal verb
examples: to see, hear or understand something or someone with difficulty
_The numbers are too small – I can't make them out at all.
_I can't make out your writing.
_She's a strange person - I can't make her out at all.
_[ + question word ]Nobody can make outwhyyou should have been attacked.

children.name: see through
children.definition: sb/sthphrasal verb
examples: to realise that someone is trying to deceive you to get an advantage, or that someone's
behaviour is intended to deceive you, and to understand the truth about the situation
_They were very friendly, but I quickly saw through them.
_She saw through his excuse at once.

children.name: understand
children.definition: verbunderstood,understoodREALISEhiểu ra
examples: [ T ]formalto know or realise something because you have been told it
_[ + ( that ) ]I understand(that)you are interested in borrowing some money from us.
_[ + that ]The Director hadgivenhertounderstand (= told her)thatshe would be promoted.
_[ + object + to infinitive ]A secret buyer is understoodtohave paid £1 million for the three pictures (= there is unofficial news that this has happened) .

children.name: take sth on board
children.definition: takesthon board
examples: to understand or accept an idea or a piece of information
_Banks need to take on board the views of their customers.

children.name: be in/out of tune with sb/sth
children.definition: be in/out of tune withsb/sth
examples: If you are in tune with people or ideas, you understand or agree with them, and if you areout of tune with them, you do not
_Much of his success comes from being in tune with what his customers want.
_Her theories were out of tune with the scientific thinking of the time.
